subject: Home & DIY
title: Galvanic Corrosion: When Metals Attack Each Other
description: A micro-lesson that makes Galvanic Corrosion: When Metals Attack Each Other usable.

hook.text: Connect copper to steel pipe and the steel corrodes rapidly. Two perfectly good metals destroy each other on contact.

buildup.text: Metals have different voltages. In moisture, touching metals form a battery‚Äîone corrodes while the other is shielded.

discovery.text: The galvanic series ranks metals: zinc and steel sacrifice to protect copper and stainless steel. The lesser dissolves.

twist.text: Plumbers use dielectric unions‚Äîinsulating fittings‚Äîbetween unlike metals. Without them, the joint corrodes in years.

climax.text: This principle protects ships: zinc 'sacrificial anodes' corrode to protect the hull. Your water heater uses it too.

punchline.text: Some metals must die to save others.

quiz.question: What causes galvanic corrosion between two different metals?
options: Different electrical potentials create a battery effect, corroding the less noble metal
Chemical reactions between the metals produce corrosive acids
Vibration between metals creates friction that wears both surfaces
